channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: In Moscow, the Fighting Is a World Away
item.description: A detachment from the battle in Ukraine is exactly what President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia is counting on as he carries out a domestic strategy of shielding his people from hardships.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins and Nanna Heitmann
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times

item.title: Russia Is Buying North Korean Artillery, According to U.S. Intelligence
item.description: Moscow’s purchase of millions of shells and rockets from North Korea is a sign that global sanctions have hampered the Russian military’s supply lines.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.media:description: Russian rockets fired during exercises this month. A shortage of artillery could be a sign of restricted supply lines for the Russian military.

item.title: Biden Administration Has Admitted One Million Migrants to Await Hearings
item.description: The presence of asylum seekers in the United States is both a humanitarian challenge and a political flash point in a divided country.
item.dc:creator: Eileen Sullivan
item.media:credit: Kirsten Luce for The New York Times
item.media:description: Asylum seekers, mostly from the Democratic Republic of Congo and Angola, occupy almost every room at a Howard Johnson hotel in South Portland, Maine.

item.title: It Was War. Then, a Rancher’s Truce With Some Pesky Beavers Paid Off.
item.description: The ‘highly skilled environmental engineers’ can help to store precious water and rejuvenate land ravaged by climate change. Just don’t dynamite their homes.
item.dc:creator: Catrin Einhorn and Niki Chan Wylie

item.title: ‘Deeply Problematic’: Experts Question Judge’s Intervention in Trump Inquiry
item.description: A ruling by a judge appointed by former President Donald J. Trump surprised specialists and could slow the documents investigation.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.media:description: Mar-a-Lago, former President Donald J. Trump’s residence and private club in Palm Beach, Fla.

item.title: Before Midterms, Election Officials Increase Security Over Threats
item.description: With violent rhetoric from the right intensifying, some election officials are bolstering their defenses. Others are quitting.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: Election workers at the Maricopa County Recorder’s Office in Phoenix in August. The county has built up its election security measures since 2020.

item.title: Biden Puts Defense of Democracy at Center of Agenda, at Home and Abroad
item.description: President Biden’s foreign policy priority overlaps with a main domestic drive — both made more urgent by the persistent power of China, Russia and Donald J. Trump.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:description: President Biden warned about the threat to democracy in the United States last week during a speech in Philadelphia.

item.title: What to Watch For in the Massachusetts Primaries
item.description: Democrats expect to reclaim the governor’s office this fall with Maura Healey, there’s a three-way Democratic primary for lieutenant governor and Boston has a messy district attorney race.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor
item.media:credit: Sophie Park for The New York Times
item.media:description: Limited public polling has shown Maura Healey, the state attorney general, with a large lead in the general election regardless of who her Republican opponent is.

item.title: How Abbott Kept Sick Babies From Becoming a Scandal
item.description: Abbott’s lawyers at Jones Day negotiated secret settlements and used scorched earth tactics with families whose infants fell ill after consuming powdered formula.
item.dc:creator: David Enrich
item.media:description: Similac is one of the powdered-baby-formula products made by Abbott Laboratories.

item.title: Saskatchewan Stabbings Suspect Found Dead, Canada’s Police Say
item.description: The body of a man being sought by the authorities was found with wounds that were not believed to be self-inflicted. The killing of 10 people stunned the country.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen, Amber Bracken and Dan Bilefsky
item.media:credit: Amber Bracken for The New York Times
item.media:description: Two officers investigating a home on Monday in Weldon, Saskatchewan, where an older man who was believed to be a victim of the mass killing lived.

item.title: Rafael Nadal Loses His Serve and His Way at the U.S. Open
item.description: His loss to Frances Tiafoe was Nadal’s earliest defeat at a major tournament in more than five years and the first time he had been beaten in any major in 2022.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Clarey
item.media:description: Rafael Nadal of Spain failed to reach the quarterfinals at the U.S. Open after losing to Frances Tiafoe of the United States.

item.title: Battling Violence and Censors, Women in China Become ‘Invisible and Absent’
item.description: The Chinese Communist Party has long promoted gender equality as a core tenet, but as cases of gender abuse make headlines, Beijing has tried to squelch dissent and control the narrative.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson and Zixu Wang
item.media:description: Zhou Xiaoxuan in August lost her appeal against a famous TV anchor she had accused of sexual assault.

item.title: David Milch Still Has Stories to Tell
item.description: The TV producer and creator of “Deadwood” recounts his tumultuous upbringing, his trailblazing career and his experience with Alzheimer’s disease in “Life’s Work.”
item.dc:creator: Dave Itzkoff
item.media:credit: Devin Oktar Yalkin for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I have lived into the vivid truth that we’re in the last innings,” Milch said. “So, be grateful, because you ought to be. There are so many gestures of kindness and humane connection.”

item.title: Debtors, Unite! You Have Nothing to Lose but Your Shame.
item.description: Conversations about debt are never purely about economics. They are always, also, conversations about power and morality.
item.dc:creator: Astra Taylor

item.title: Liz Truss, Britain’s Next Prime Minister, Is Still in Thrall to the Empire
item.description: Liz Truss is absorbed in imperial thinking.
item.dc:creator: Kojo Koram
item.media:description: Liz Truss, Britain’s incoming prime minister.

item.title: Lea Michele, ’Funny Girl’ and the Question of Second Chances
item.description: On Lea Michele and the matter of second chances.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Bennett
item.media:credit: Gioncarlo Valentine for The New York Times

item.title: Why Gorbachev Mattered
item.description: Gorbachev’s dream of a democratic, prosperous Russia at peace with its neighbors has been dashed.
item.dc:creator: James A. Baker, III

item.title: Jonathan Pie on Liz Truss, Britain’s Next Prime Minister
item.description: With Liz Truss as its next prime minister, Britain is about to get a second helping of the policies that created its current crisis.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Pie and Adam Westbrook

item.title: Education in America: School Is for Making Citizens
item.description: Public education requires lessons about history and also contact with and context about other Americans: who we are and what has made us.
item.dc:creator: Heather C. McGhee and Victor Ray
item.media:credit: Illustration by Chloe Scheffe; photographs by Library of Congress; AlexMSchool, Calsidyrose and Mikus, via Wikimedia Commons; and Mika Baumeister and Dima Shishkov, via Unsplash.

item.title: Education in America: School Is for Wasting Time and Money
item.description: I have deep doubts about the intellectual and social value of schooling.
item.dc:creator: Bryan Caplan
item.media:credit: Illustration by Chloe Scheffe; photographs by Internet Archive; Warren K. Leffler, via Library of Congress; photos-public-domain.com; and Charles Deluvio and Subhash Nusetti, via Unsplash

item.title: A Good Issue for Democrats
item.description: Despite the large partisan gaps on many aspects of Covid, Americans give Democrats higher marks for pandemic management than Republicans.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt

item.title: A User’s Guide to the Midterm Elections
item.description: What happens in November won’t just be about who wins and who loses. Astead W. Herndon, the host of “The Run-Up,” explains why the stakes are so high.
item.dc:creator: Michael Barbaro, Rachel Quester, Nina Feldman, Jessica Cheung, Eric Krupke, Lisa Tobin, Paige Cowett, Marion Lozano, Rowan Niemisto, Dan Powell and Chris Wood
item.media:credit: Photo illustration: The New York Times; Photo: Samuel Corum for The New York Times

item.title: How Many Drinks a Week Are Safe? Canada Considers a Much Lower Limit
item.description: Research to update Canada’s drinking guideline has found that there are no health benefits, only dangers, from alcohol.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: Research has found that consuming more than six drinks per week greatly increases health risks.

item.title: What Are Your Lessons From Remote Work?
item.description: We’re looking for advice.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Biden Administration Releases Plan for $50 Billion Investment in Chips
item.description: The Commerce Department issued guidelines for companies angling to receive federal funding aimed at bolstering the domestic semiconductor industry.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:description: The Commerce Department has said its goal is to encourage the production of leading-edge semiconductors and shore up the supply of chips currently in use.

item.title: As Ex-Uber Executive Heads to Trial, the Security Community Reels
item.description: Joe Sullivan, Uber’s former chief of security, faces criminal charges for his handling of a 2016 security breach. His trial this week has divided the security industry.
item.dc:creator: Kashmir Hill and Kellen Browning
item.media:description: Joe Sullivan in 2010. He faces charges over his handling of a 2016 security breach at Uber, where he led security from 2015 to 2017.

item.title: In India’s Tech Capital, Floods Leave Workers Riding Tractors to Work
item.description: Bengaluru, India’s Silicon Valley, joined the roster of places in South Asia inundated by torrential rains during this monsoon season.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir and Emily Schmall
item.media:description: People pulled a car through a water-logged road following torrential rains in Bengaluru, on Monday.

item.title: New York Is Pushed to Stop Asking Aspiring Lawyers About Long-Ago Crimes
item.description: To become a lawyer in New York, one must share details of sealed cases and juvenile records. Critics say that the requirement may be illegal, and that it harms racial diversity.
item.dc:creator: Troy Closson
item.media:credit: Mary Inhea Kang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dylan James, who as a high school student robbed an acquaintance, says he wants to transcend a youthful mistake.

item.title: How to Cope With Fall Anxiety
item.description: As the most carefree weeks of the year draw to a close, pay close attention to your emotions. They might be telling you something useful.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer

item.title: The Secret to Raising a Resilient Kid
item.description: The ability to bounce back is more important now than ever; here’s how to impart it
item.dc:creator: Erik Vance

item.title: What to Know About the New Covid Booster Shots
item.description: New shots targeting the latest version of the Omicron variant will be available soon. When should you get yours? Here’s what experts recommend.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum
item.media:credit: Charity Rachelle for The New York Times
item.media:description: The new shots target the Omicron subvariant BA.5, the dominant version of the virus.

item.title: At Lincoln Center, Addicted to Swing and Back on the Dance Floor
item.description: After a pandemic hiatus, dancing under the stars has returned, uniting old friends and acquaintances.
item.dc:creator: Julia Jacobs, Rachel Sherman and Evelyn Freja
item.category: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts
item.media:description: A giant disco ball reigned over the Lincoln Center dance floor this summer, and a miniature one adorned a dancer on Lindy Hop night.
